value: <l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">27</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">The play then owes its <add hand="ms" place="above">heightened</add> intensity to the audience in the</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">penny seats. At their 
            <choice>
              <sic>commandit</sic>
              <corr>command it</corr>
            </choice> is violent; it is 
            <choice>
              <sic>corase</sic>
              <corr>coarse</corr>
            </choice>;</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">it is, like our own detective stories and best sellers</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">a parody and a transformation of actual fact. There was a</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><add hand="ms" place="above">It must have</add> great temptation for the playwright to exaggerate. It</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><del hand="ms">was</del> <add hand="ms" place="above">fed</add> the desire of the audience in the penny seats. But in the</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">seats in the covered part of 
            <choice>
              <sic>th</sic>
              <corr>the</corr>
            </choice> house there were nobles,</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">rulers scholars. Lord Southampton and Lord Rutland,</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">Roland White wrote to Sir Robert Sidney <quote source="#" rend="inline">"pass away their</quote></l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><quote source="#" rend="inline">time in London, merely in going to plays every day"</quote>.</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">Yet they are silent too. A 
            <choice>
              <sic>yo ng</sic>
              <corr>young</corr>
            </choice> poet dedicates his sonnets</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">to Mr W. H. and none of them troubles to ask,</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">
            <choice>
              <sic>Whois</sic>
              <corr>Who is</corr>
            </choice> this patron? It is not a matter of interest in court</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">circles. And 
            <choice>
              <sic>is</sic>
              <corr>this</corr>
            </choice> lack of curiosity is harder to explain.</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">
            <choice>
              <sic>Fo</sic>
              <corr>For</corr>
            </choice> they were readers; they had the Greeks and the Latins</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">at the 
            <choice>
              <sic>ack</sic>
              <corr>back</corr>
            </choice> of their minds. How could it have been that they</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">said nothing about 
            <choice>
              <sic>theis</sic>
              <corr>this</corr>
            </choice> astonishing new art, that they</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">did not <add hand="ms" place="above">[expect?]</add> 
            <choice>
              <sic>expereince</sic>
              <corr>experience</corr>
            </choice> that sense of outrage, of 
            <choice>
              <sic>partisanchip</sic>
              <corr>partisanship</corr>
            </choice></l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">which seems to be the common reaction of the more cultivated</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">part of the public when a new writer of genius appears?</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">Perhaps <rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-fbac" key="Bacon, Francis">Bacon</rs> in his <rs type="literary-work" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-fbac" key="Essays (Francis Bacon)">Essays</rs> 
            <choice>
              <sic>supplys</sic>
              <corr>supplies</corr>
            </choice> a reason.</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><quote source="#" rend="inline">These things be 
            <choice>
              <sic>b y</sic>
              <corr>but</corr>
            </choice> Toyes"</quote> he wrote in the essay</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">called <rs type="literary-work" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#lit-masq" key="Of Masques and Triumphs">"Of Masques and Triumphs"</rs>. To the 
            <choice>
              <sic>aristocratuc</sic>
              <corr>aristocratic</corr>
            </choice></l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">scholar the players were still only mountebanks, bear leaders</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">and 
            <choice>
              <sic>acroats</sic>
              <corr>acrobats</corr>
            </choice>. They spoke in the vulgar tongue. Off the stage</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">they lived in the <rs type="literary-work" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#lit-hear" key="Heart of Darkness, The">heart of darkness</rs>. 
            <rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-cmar" key="Marlowe, Christopher"><choice>
              <sic>Marloew</sic>
              <corr>Marlowe</corr>
            </choice></rs> lying on the</l>
